slides.title: Welcome to Mechanical Engineering
slides.content:
# Introduction to Mechanical Engineering

Welcome to **Mechanical Engineering** - designing machines!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Statics and Dynamics** - Forces and motion
- **Mechanics of Materials** - Stress and strain
- **Thermodynamics** - Heat and energy
- **Machine Design** - Creating systems
- **Manufacturing** - Making things

> **Fun Fact:** Mechanical engineering is one of the oldest and broadest engineering disciplines!

slides.title: Statics
slides.content:
# Statics

## Equilibrium Conditions:
- Sum of forces = 0
- Sum of moments = 0

## Free Body Diagrams:
1. Isolate the object
2. Show all external forces
3. Apply equilibrium equations

## Types of Supports:

| Support | Reactions |
|---------|----------|
| Roller | 1 force (perpendicular) |
| Pin | 2 forces (any direction) |
| Fixed | 2 forces + 1 moment |

## Applications:
- Trusses
- Frames
- Machines

slides.title: Dynamics
slides.content:
# Dynamics

## Kinematics (motion description):
- Position, velocity, acceleration
- Linear and angular motion

## Kinetics (forces and motion):
- F = ma (Newton's second law)
- Moment = I x alpha

## Energy Methods:
- Kinetic energy: KE = 0.5 x m x v^2
- Potential energy: PE = m x g x h
- Work-energy theorem

## Momentum:
- Linear: p = m x v
- Conservation in collisions

## Rotation:
- Angular velocity: omega
- Angular acceleration: alpha
- Moment of inertia: I

slides.title: Stress and Strain
slides.content:
# Stress and Strain

## Stress (sigma):
```
sigma = F / A
```
Units: Pa (N/m^2) or psi

## Strain (epsilon):
```
epsilon = delta_L / L
```
Dimensionless

## Hooke's Law:
```
sigma = E x epsilon
```
E = Young's modulus (material stiffness)

## Stress-Strain Curve:
- Elastic region (linear)
- Yield point
- Plastic region
- Ultimate strength
- Fracture

slides.title: Types of Loading
slides.content:
# Types of Loading

| Type | Description | Formula |
|------|------------|--------|
| Tension | Pulling apart | sigma = F/A |
| Compression | Pushing together | sigma = F/A |
| Shear | Sliding forces | tau = F/A |
| Torsion | Twisting | tau = T*r/J |
| Bending | Curving | sigma = M*y/I |

## Material Properties:
- Yield strength
- Ultimate tensile strength
- Modulus of elasticity
- Poisson's ratio
- Ductility vs brittleness

slides.title: Thermodynamics Laws
slides.content:
# Laws of Thermodynamics

## Zeroth Law:
If A and B are in thermal equilibrium with C, then A and B are in equilibrium.

## First Law:
Energy conservation:
```
dU = Q - W
```
- dU = change in internal energy
- Q = heat added
- W = work done by system

## Second Law:
Entropy of isolated system never decreases.
- Heat flows from hot to cold
- No 100% efficient heat engine

## Third Law:
Entropy approaches zero as temperature approaches absolute zero.

slides.title: Heat Transfer
slides.content:
# Heat Transfer

## Conduction:
- Through solid material
- Fourier's Law: q = -k x dT/dx
- k = thermal conductivity

## Convection:
- Through fluid motion
- q = h x A x delta_T
- h = convection coefficient

## Radiation:
- Electromagnetic waves
- Stefan-Boltzmann: q = epsilon x sigma x A x T^4
- No medium required

## Applications:
- Heat exchangers
- Insulation design
- Cooling systems

slides.title: Thermodynamic Cycles
slides.content:
# Thermodynamic Cycles

| Cycle | Application | Efficiency |
|-------|-------------|------------|
| Carnot | Ideal (maximum) | 1 - Tc/Th |
| Otto | Gasoline engines | ~25-30% |
| Diesel | Diesel engines | ~35-40% |
| Rankine | Steam power plants | ~35-45% |
| Brayton | Gas turbines | ~30-40% |
| Refrigeration | Cooling systems | COP |

## Key Components:
- Compressor
- Heat exchangers
- Turbine/expander
- Pump

slides.title: Machine Elements
slides.content:
# Machine Elements

## Power Transmission:

| Element | Function |
|---------|-----------|
| Gears | Transfer rotation, change speed/torque |
| Belts | Flexible power transfer |
| Chains | Positive drive |
| Shafts | Transmit torque |
| Couplings | Connect shafts |

## Support Elements:
- Bearings (reduce friction)
- Bushings
- Seals

## Fasteners:
- Bolts and screws
- Rivets
- Welds

slides.title: Gear Systems
slides.content:
# Gear Systems

## Gear Types:

| Type | Application |
|------|-------------|
| Spur | Parallel shafts |
| Helical | Smooth, quiet |
| Bevel | Intersecting shafts |
| Worm | High reduction |
| Rack and pinion | Linear motion |

## Gear Ratio:
```
GR = N_driven / N_driver = omega_in / omega_out
```

## Torque Relationship:
```
T_out / T_in = GR
```

## Applications:
- Transmissions
- Clocks
- Industrial machinery

slides.title: Fatigue and Failure
slides.content:
# Fatigue and Failure

## Fatigue:
- Failure under repeated loading
- Below ultimate strength
- Progressive crack growth

## S-N Curve:
- Stress vs Number of cycles
- Endurance limit (some materials)
- Design for fatigue life

## Failure Modes:
- Yielding (permanent deformation)
- Fracture (breaking)
- Fatigue (cyclic loading)
- Creep (high temperature)
- Corrosion

## Design Approach:
- Factor of safety
- Stress concentration avoidance
- Material selection

slides.title: Manufacturing Processes
slides.content:
# Manufacturing Processes

## Shaping:

| Process | Description |
|---------|-------------|
| Casting | Pour molten metal |
| Forging | Shape by compression |
| Rolling | Reduce thickness |
| Extrusion | Push through die |
| Drawing | Pull through die |

## Material Removal:
- Turning (lathe)
- Milling
- Drilling
- Grinding

## Joining:
- Welding
- Brazing
- Adhesives
- Mechanical fasteners

slides.title: CAD/CAE
slides.content:
# Computer-Aided Design and Engineering

## CAD (Design):
- 2D drafting
- 3D solid modeling
- Assembly design
- Drawing generation

## CAE (Analysis):
- Finite Element Analysis (FEA)
- Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD)
- Multibody dynamics
- Optimization

## FEA Process:
1. Create geometry
2. Mesh the model
3. Apply boundary conditions
4. Solve
5. Post-process results

## Common Software:
- SolidWorks, CATIA, AutoCAD
- ANSYS, Abaqus, NASTRAN

slides.title: Summary
slides.content:
# Mechanical Engineering Summary

## Mechanics:
- Statics: F = 0, M = 0
- Dynamics: F = ma
- Stress = F/A, Strain = dL/L

## Thermodynamics:
- Energy conservation (1st law)
- Entropy increases (2nd law)
- Heat engines and refrigeration

## Machine Design:
- Gears, bearings, shafts
- Fatigue analysis
- CAD/CAE tools

## Manufacturing:
- Casting, forging, machining
- Joining methods

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Mechanical Engineering!
